content: This thread is for the issue Equation Explorer: Allow searching/displaying any equation

image.png

This is the layout of the equation explorer when an equation id within the range [1, 4694] is searched for.
For an equation id > 4694 will there be any need to show the implication tables?
@Vlad Tsyrklevich @Bruno Le Floch

With @Alex Meiburg we had started to work out implications between selected high-order equations (e.g., those in the Tour of selected equations) and the low-order ones, so there can be some data. But for most equations we won't have any implication data. Maybe there should be two layouts depending on whether implication data is available or not?

A crazy idea could be to compile Vampire (written mostly in C++) to WASM (Javascript) and work out most implications on the fly (computed client-side), but I don't think this is quite reasonable.

Either way, an important point is to display the commentary, we have quite a lot of it. Some commentary on low-order equations point to some higher-order ones which are presently broken links since the Equation Explorer doesn't know how to display anything above order 4.

I'll look into those implications between high-order equations and low order ones.

Instead of 2 layouts, how about not displaying any data? Or not displaying any data might be misleading as people might think there are no implications?

A crazy idea could be to compile Vampire (written mostly in C++) to WASM (Javascript) and work out most implications on the fly (computed client-side), but I don't think this is quite reasonable.

This is interesting, but there are probably too many things to account for in doing this.

Currently, I've been able to port find_equation_id.py to javascript, and link it up with the equation explorer code. It errors out when renderingImplications for high-order equations, but I should be able to get it fixed soon.

I see how 2 layouts may be more beneficial than just empty fields. For a second layout how about a similar looking table with the text No Implication Data Found ?

I think just showing the equation name (and commentary if available) with nothing else would already be an improvement. We do have a few implications between higher order equations but right now the way the explorer works has a very rigid data format that makes it hard to extend. At first just being able to see higher order equations would already be an improvement without showing any of those implications
Alright

A variant of what Vlad is suggesting would be to put all 4694 laws in the "Unknown" columns of the two tables ("This equation implies" and "This equation is implied by"). This way you don't have to come up with any new layout.

My recent experiments with Mace4 and Prover9 shows that 98.8% of low-order implications are resolved by counterexamples of size ≤3 or by proofs with very small search parameters (and very short time). So at least in terms of amount of computational work it would be feasible to work out most implications on the fly and have a reasonably small number of unknowns. Of course this is quite difficult to program.

I think this varient of putting all 4694 laws in the "Unknown" columns of the two tables (unless in cases where it is known based on the implications between selected high-order equations and low-order ones you worked on with @Alex Meiburg ) makes more sense than creating a new layout where the tables do not exist or there is a table with no implication data.
I should have something up by today or tomorrow.
When convenient, let me know in what form you need the implication data from selected high-order laws to low-order laws. (And whether they have to be formalized in Lean.)
Okay
I don't think we should display anything that's not formalized and there's already a pipeline for formalized implications going to the explorer

@Vlad Tsyrklevich The commentary has some information (such as "this equation implies that left multiplications are bijective" or "this equation implies that the right-cubing map is involutive") that has not been formalized. Should it be formalized?

I think commentary is different, in my mind the point of the explorer is a front-end to the main aim of the project: the formalized database of implications. At this late point the only reason I see to change anything is that it would be helpful to 1) be able to see higher-numbered equations online and 2) maybe also view formalized implications outside of the original set of equations. Otherwise I would personally be hesitant to make any changes to the web-app frontends since the project is wrapped up and most people are not paying sufficient attention to verify results and confirm that bugs haven't creeped in.

Currently from what I have, if a high-order equation is searched for, this is the only data that comes up, I just cut off the output for Equation4694 to demonstrate.
image.png

If it were an equation within the 4694 it will look something like this:
image.png

Commentary still shows for high-order equations if any are available. Like in the image below:
image.png

If we're going with just being able to display high-order equations, its dual and commentary if any (for now), I can make a pr with current changes which support these and also the displaying of equation 1 (which the current explorer cannot display cause of a minor issue that got introduced when we switched to zero based indexing).

Then continue working to:

  • Put all 4694 laws in the "Unknown" columns of the two tables.
  • Plug in the implication data from selected high-order laws to low-order laws.
While you all are modifying the site, can someone add a button somewhere on the equation explorer page to return to the main page ( https://teorth.github.io/equational_theories/ ) ?
Sure.
I think the finite magma explorer and graphiti also don't have such links.
I'll check and add them if not already there.

Updated:

high-oder equation without commentary -
image.png

high-order equation with commentary -
image.png

image.png

For graphiti I think the link back to the home page can be added to one of these urls at the top here.
Thinking of calling it Back to EQT

@Matthew Bolan
I like this compromise of just displaying commentary but not implications for higher order equations, look forward to the PR!

Are you also tackling showing commentary on an equivalent law for equations that are not minimal representatives of their equivalence class? And the similar question of showing the commentary of the dual law if the equation has no commentary but its dual does?

duals are exported as a list, the explorer doesn't generate them so it doesn't know them for higher orders. With no implications exported for higher-order equations, there are no equivalence classes at the moment
@Vlad Tsyrklevich I've updated the explorer to dynamically generate duals, so duals are displayed for higher order equations currently. As shown in one of the images above.
Ah, indeed--I hadn't noticed that.

@Bruno Le Floch I didn't change the way commentary gets shown, so as long as the commentary for the equation exists in implications.js it should pop up.

image.png
If the equation has no commentary but its dual does, when the user clicks on the link to view the dual equation then the user sees the commentary also, if it exists in implications.js

My point is that it's a bit of a shame that https://teorth.github.io/equational_theories/implications/?928 shows no indication that its equivalent law 543 is Tarski's axiom 543 characterizing abelian group subtraction, or https://teorth.github.io/equational_theories/implications/?1090 is equivalent to the dual of 543. A user would have no idea to go to the dual of 1090, which is 2552, and then see at the bottom of the page that it is equivalent to 543 which has commentary.

Okay, I get what you mean now.

For this:

And the similar question of showing the commentary of the dual law if the equation has no commentary but its dual does?

I should be able to easily implement this now.

I'll look into this:

Are you also tackling showing commentary on an equivalent law for equations that are not minimal representatives of their equivalence class?

Currently I am working on adding a link back to the main eqt home page to the finite magma explorer.

For showing commentary of the dual, does something like this work? I specified that it is the commentary of the dual being show within the commentary box:

image.png

For the case where the equation itself has commentary, the commentary of the dual does not show up (though I can always append the commentary of the dual if needed and if it exists):

image.png

I added 2 links on the finite magma explorer, one to the main website, and the other to the equation explorer, since the equation explorer has links which lead directly to the finite magma explorer:

image.png

For graphiti, I added Back to EQT link at the top of this page:

image.png

Then for the search page, I made the Equation Explorer text a clickable link, and added a Back to EQT link at the bottom:

image.png

I think we used ETP as a short hand for Equational Theories Project, maybe that is a better acronym than EQT for the Graphiti page?

The display of the dual commentary is great! The equation and its dual almost never have commentary: I made sure to put the commentary in whichever has the smallest number. There are a handful of exceptions: laws 4&5, laws 38&39 come to mind. In all of these cases, the commentary of dual equations are basically identical, with left and right interchanged (which is why I felt it useful to keep both commentaries separate).
I'll update EQT -> ETP then.

Updated:

image.png

image.png

Currently, the explorer:

  • Checks the equation for commentary.
  • Checks the dual of the equation for commentary.
  • Checks all equivalents in the equivalence class of the equation for commentary.
  • Checks all equivalents in the equivalence class of the dual equation for commentary.

The checks do not happen concurrently; if one succeeds, the others are skipped.

I thought of also checking the duals of equivalents in the equivalence class of the equation for commentary, but the thought of getting the dual for each equation (using Equation.fromId(eqId).dual()) then checking this dual for commentary via a loop will significantly slow the program down, so I did not add it. But it can be added if anyone feels the need for it.

Currently, with the four checks above, the second case @Bruno Le Floch spoke of

My point is that it's a bit of a shame that https://teorth.github.io/equational_theories/implications/?928 shows no indication that its equivalent law 543 is Tarski's axiom 543 characterizing abelian group subtraction, or https://teorth.github.io/equational_theories/implications/?1090 is equivalent to the dual of 543. A user would have no idea to go to the dual of 1090, which is 2552, and then see at the bottom of the page that it is equivalent to 543 which has commentary.

has been covered as shown in the images below:

  1. Showing commentary for dual equations:
    image.png

  2. Showing commentary for equation in the equivalence class of the current equation:
    image.png

  3. Showing commentary for equation in the equivalence class of the dual of the current equation:
    image.png

That's great! You can speed things up by taking the minimal numbered law in the equivalence class instead of looping through equivalents, and same thing for the equivalence class of the dual. So in order of priority it should be

  • The equation's commentary.
  • The dual's commentary.
  • The (lowest-numbered equivalent)'s commentary.
  • The (lowest-numbered equivalent of the dual)'s commentary.

This removal of loops is pretty important for the huge equivalence class of E2. For instance it would be useful if you could check that showing E15 (say) is still fast, and that showing E1689 still shows the commentary file numbered 1689 (even though that equation is equivalent to E2).

The order you chose for the second and third points seems good both for efficiency and for the following cas: for E1923, your code will show the commentary of its dual E1689, whereas swapping these two points would show the commentary of the equivalent E2, which is less relevant.

No need to look at duals of each equivalent law, since these are the same as the equivalence class of the dual.

Instead of just Commentary of the equivalent (Equation 543), do you think it would make sense to write Commentary of the equivalent Equation543[x=y◇(z◇(x◇(y◇z))))], to keep the display similar for all equations on the page, and for the user to know which equation it is about? Not everyone knows their equation numbers by heart, and the commentary typically doesn't repeat the equations.

The equivalence class of E2 will never enter a loop since E2 has commentary, but I understand what you mean.

Checking E2, E15 and E1689:
Screencast From 2025-11-05 14-47-46.mp4

The loop breaks early once it finds commentary and will not even run at all if the equation itself has commentary or the dual has commentary.
Worst case scenario would've been in high-order equations, but points 3&4 are skipped for them.

Will the code that generates the equivalence classes always do so in ascending order?
image.png
If it does, then I won't need to sort before getting the smallest equation id.

I'll remove the loops in point 3 and 4 so it becomes:

  • The (lowest-numbered equivalent)'s commentary.
  • The (lowest-numbered equivalent of the dual)'s commentary.
    and sort if necessary.

Then update the format Commentary of the equivalent (Equation 543) to Commentary of the equivalent Equation543[x=y◇(z◇(x◇(y◇z))))] to keep the display similar and also to display both equation and equation number.

Updates have been made:

  1. Lowest-numbered equivalent's commentary is used instead of looping through equivalence class.
  2. Lowest-numbered equivalent of dual's commentary is shown instead of looping through equivalence class of dual.
  3. Updated instance of Equation {eqId} to use Equation{eqId}[{quation}] for consistency.

image.png

image.png

I think all the boxes have been checked, so I'm going to update the pr so its ready for review.

Updated the pr: https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/1288

Too many changes made, hence breaking up into multiple PRs as suggested by @Vlad Tsyrklevich in this comment https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/1288#issuecomment-3493049034

Link to thread on Zulip

Description:
Before addressing this pr, you might want to take a look at #1375
This pr was broken up from #1288
This pr resolves issue #848

  • Port scripts/find_equation_id.py to js scripts/find_equation_id.js
  • Copy scripts/find_equation_id.js and modify for use in the equation explorer as home_page/implications/find_equation_id_1.js suffixing with _1 since home_page/implications/find_equation_id.js already exists but does not seem to be a proper port of scripts/find_equation_id.py

  • Preserve code no longer in use from home_page/implications/find_equation_id.js as per discussion here

Link to thread on Zulip

Description:
Before addressing this pr, you might want to take a look at #1376
This pr was broken up from #1288

Commentary is displayed for equations in the following order of priority:

  • The equation's commentary.
  • The dual's commentary.
  • The (lowest-numbered equivalent)'s commentary.
  • The (lowest-numbered equivalent of the dual)'s commentary.

Link to thread on Zulip

pr: https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/1379

@Terence Tao Would you mind leaving the front-end PRs up to get reviewed? This code is fragile, and unlike with the Lean component of the project, there's no guard rails to ensure changes are correct.

Ah, sorry about that. I don't know how to run the code for EE locally, so I thought one had to push it to the repo to test it out; but if you are able to review it without doing so then I will leave it. Would you like me to revert any of the PRs I approved?
I think it would be best if we reverted and then reviewed them rather than trying to review backwards. I'd submit a PR to do so myself but I have to run atm
The comments on the PRs currently, should I address them there or after they get created again I address them?
I have responded to all the comments on github @Vlad Tsyrklevich
OK, I have reverted the latest two PRs for this. There is a third PR I could also revert, though this one seemed innocuous (mostly updating links)

@Vlad Tsyrklevich the new PRs are up I've applied all the feedback from the previous one's.

[FEATURE] Allow displaying of higher order equations by explorer

[ENHANCE] Improve Commentary Display

I've also updated this one:

[FEATURE] Allow displaying of higher order equations by explorer
Thanks! Taking a look now

I left some feedback on #1379/#1383. I verified that equations 1-4694 and sampled higher-order equations match what we know is correct for mapping equation id -> equation. I also verified duals match dual computations for equations up to order 5. So things look good from a data consistency perspective. I need to run for the rest of the day, but I think I should be able to finish reviews tomorrow.
I have addressed all the comments you left on github.
@Vlad Tsyrklevich the PRs have been updated.

When https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/1386 gets merged, would it make sense to replace the image of the equation explorer displaying equation 42 currently on page 53 of the paper:

Screenshot_2025-12-04_16-02-29.png

with the image below, which displays equation 42 with commentary?

image.png
Sure, it makes sense to use the most current version.
In that case this specific commentary should be triple-checked since it would end up in the paper.

Screenshot_2025-12-04_18-44-34.png

It matches up with what's in commentary/Equation38.md and in home_page/implications/implications.js below:

Screenshot_2025-12-04_18-47-01.png

and Equation38 is the equation with the smallest id in the equivalence class of Equation42.

Also here in page 3 of this paper: https://pu.edu.pk/images/journal/maths/PDF/Paper-9_50_3_2018.pdf

Screenshot_2025-12-04_20-03-11.png

and on this wikipedia page: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magma_(algebra)

Screenshot_2025-12-04_21-24-08.png

The equation being reffered to as The Left Unar Law is Equation42 though, but the commentary is attached to Equation38, which makes sense since @Bruno Le Floch made sure to put the commentary in the equation with the smallest number(id) in the equivalence class as mentioned earlier in this conversation, I think.

I wasn't worried about your code picking up the wrong commentary file, but rather about the rest of the text, copied here, which has many independent claims:

  1. E38 magmas ⇔ sets with endofunction.
  2. The list of laws of order ≤4 implying E38 or its dual E39 is [4, 5, 13, 24, 38, 39, 41, 62, 256, 336, 374, 463, 3051, 3359, 4117].
  3. Such laws describe sets with endofunctions subject to a condition.
  4. The equivalence class of this law consists of 40 laws (among laws of order ≤4).
  5. 57% of the 4694 laws imply either E38 or E39.
  6. E38 cannot hold in a non-trivial quasigroup.
  7. (E38 + commutativity) ⇔ E41 (constant law).
  8. (E38 + associativity) ⇔ E374 x◇y = (x◇x)◇x.
  9. E38 magmas are always submagmas of linear E38 magmas.
  10. The free E38 magma on generators Σ is ℕ×Σ with (m,s) ◇ (n,t) = (m+1,s).
  11. The fine spectrum is given by OEIS A001372.

Contents of Equation38.md

The left unar law

This law states that the magma operation is left-projection composed with squaring, namely x◇y = S(x) where S: x ↦ x◇x. Such magmas are in one-to-one correspondence with sets equipped with an endofunction (self-map).

Any law that implies this law or its dual (laws 4, 5, 13, 24, 38, 39, 41, 62, 256, 336, 374, 463, 3051, 3359, 4117 and higher-order laws) describes sets equipped with a self-map subject to a condition. The equivalence class of this law is among the largest ones (40 laws in our list of 4694 laws), and a full 57% of the 4694 laws imply either law 38 or law 39.

This law cannot hold in any non-trivial quasigroup. In a commutative magma it is equivalent to the constant law. This law together with associativity is equivalent to law 374. Magmas satisfying this law are always submagmas of linear magmas satisfying this law.

The free magma on some set Σ of generators for this law is ℕ×Σ with S(m,s)=(m+1,s), namely (m,s) ◇ (n,t) = (m+1,s).

The number of magmas of size n (modulo isomorphism) satisfying this law is OEIS sequence A001372.

Given the ongoing momentum towards a very quick submission to arXiv, and the fact that the Equation Explorer changes have not been deployed, I suggest leaving the current figure as it is, and changing it for a journal submission. Unless @Vlad Tsyrklevich wants to rush to review and merge the corresponding PR (which one is it @Osalotioman ?).
@Vlad Tsyrklevich has already finished his review of the PR and it's just left to merge.
I've just merged the new EE changes, but I agree that the updating of the images can be decoupled from the more time sensitive issue of submitting to the arXiv.
